movie_review_blurb: Why, oh why, oh why? Oh. Why?
In Mountain Men, Labine and his cast achieve a hard-to-strike balance of comedy and heart-felt drama while maintaining a subtleness that respects your adult attention span.
Jean-Pierre Melville presents a murky criminal underworld in his gangland classic.
A snappy animated comedy with a lovely, gooey, sentimental heart.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The message will stay with you, but so will the nagging sense that you can't really do anything unless you happen to be a world leader.
The script has many glaring flaws, chiefly, that it never explains why G's inspirational speeches about steering clear of materialism and useless products actually sell the things in question.
Rubins ultimately sinks beneath the weight of its own gubbins.
This is tension-free torture porn, whose perpetrator's actions aren't just banal and consequence-free, they're endlessly justified by an abusive back-story.
Sigourney Weaver? After Avatar, surely she doesn't need the cash?

There's a stonking cast - Paul Bettany as the waitress's disabled partner, Rita Tushingham as a knackered caff worker, Olivia Williams as the glossy fiancee - but they're saddled with dialogue sagging with thematic relevance or site-specific colour.
It ties its strands together a touch too tightly two-thirds of the way through - but still leaves enough hanging at the end to be credible.
Jason Statham is matched with Robert de Niro and Clive Owen in this headcracking hitman yarn, but it's a bit overcomplicated for its own good.
There's a badly ill-judged cameo from Hugh Jackman, but also a good spoonful of laugh-out-loud gags, particularly those involving the red tape of local civic talent contests.
William Freidkin's film is full-frontal in every sense, an unabashed pulp romp stuffed with ugly acts and primal screams.

People raised their hands in joy when Coppola announced he was returning to horror after his recent wobbly adventures in the arthouse. They'll be begging him to reconsider - or perhaps just simply to stop - after seeing this.

The Deep Blue Sea remains flat as a duck pond, the prisoner of a story whose relevance, even in metaphor, has lost much of its sting, and whose dialogue has more than a whiff of a French and Saunders sketch...
A gripping ensemble piece, good-humoured even at the end of its tether.
A genuinely grotesque horror film that lurches between gleeful sadism and tedious romance without apparent validation...
movie_title: Revenge: A Love Story (Fuk sau che chi sei) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Take this Waltz confirms Polley as a serious, intelligent talent.
It's the stuff of high school horror movies: can you stop the most popular girl in school from stabbing you in the back?
A drama of unusual nuance. It lingers, spawns thoughts, connections, as a great film ought.
Those who enter the cinema unstirred by either the sport or by the joys of stats are unlikely to come out converts.
Its sole claim to fame may turn out to be as the most slyly foul-mouthed children's film yet made.
A film that aims for quirk-cachet yet somehow winds up in that hinterland between actually funny and simply irritating.
movie_title: Kawa no soko kara konnichi wa (Sawako Decides) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Smacks first of obfuscation, then of desperation.
No wonder Butler fancied taking this on: it's a terrific fit for his own brand of soulful aggression - half saint, half psychopath.
In order for the script to crackle and the heart to move, you need to suspend more disbelief that proves possible here.
Natural Selection ticks all the boxes with a firm grip. Its opening alone is a lovely cinematic coup.
Jools and Linda left my giggle chain unyanked and their backstory, for all its nuance and aspects of tragedy, failed to stir my soul.

Keshavarz uses a trowel to feed us her ideas about living under a repressive regime when all you required was a teaspoon. But she has enough promise to keep you curious for her next offering - if she can just get a lighter grip on the ladle.
It's got a cast to kill for, a Seth Rogen/Evan Goldberg script (they wrote Superbad) and a promisingly Ghostbusters-ish premise. And yet it's catastrophic.
It lays on lashings of crim-bickering and jauntily scored arterial spurting when all you can stomach is some crispbread.
The script acts on the film as a rock does when strapped to a corpse, but there's a certain noirish sheen to the cinematography that means the whole thing slips down sweeter than it really ought.
As a calling card for director Alastair Siddons, it's polished and impressive. As an experience, it requires slightly more patience than it consistently rewards.
Robert Heath's horror is riddled with plot holes and atrocious dialogue, but has a couple of brilliantly bananas performances and the odd crunchy jump.
Rebecca Thomas's gauzy debut about a 15-year-old Mormon who believes she's had an immaculate conception is deftly done.
It treads lightly on the earth: an example, as well as an education.
Todd Graff's film sags badly in the middle and is clunky with social context (recession, Asperger's), but there's enough good heart to see you through.
Even those allergic to Cruise would struggle to resist his magnetism grinning one-handed from the highest skyscraper in the world, cool as a cucumber, ripped as celery.
Neither the subject nor director ask for sympathy; what emerges is a nuanced hymn to the human spirit that still saddens, even when it inspires.
Snappy editing helps sustain some pace, and Giles Alderson has charisma as the mysterious "Infurnari", but after a spell the interest sag is unstaunchable.
The peripheral interviews with the extended Spicer family are as compelling as the central quest; this is a film with rare honesty and nuance in a field that frequently feels queasy.
Doherty hints at his charisma. But for the time being, he'd be advised to stick to the strumming.
movie_title: Confession of a Child of the Century (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There's a whole heap of Americana to wallow in here, but it's testimony to the director and subject that Buck still trots along at such a lick.
Transit delivers little of value, and never with a smile.

A restrained, nearly austere ensemble drama that manages to intertwine a dozen different stories without tripping up on any of them, it relies on real-life survivor testimony for almost every line and incident, to immensely moving and dignified effect.
If you found Transformers just a touch too subtle, this is the film for you.
Despite some tonal wobbles, and a vague sense of deja vu, it's rather charming, and sometimes genuinely sad.
To kick Sue Bourne's documentary about the 40th Irish Dancing World Championships feels both mean and ill-advised - these people sure know how to use their tootsies.
It's machine-tooled to raise smiles, swell hearts, and tickle tear ducts, yet it does so with sufficient cross-cultural cred you don't feel too yanked.
For all its absurdity and the family friendly bloodlessness (despite the copious violence), it spins along very smoothly and efficiently.
This is a tale of mistaken identities and mysterious dames, strange agencies and impromptu heroics - an unabashed entertainment, moving, amusing, difficult to resist.
You'd learn more just watching one of their films.
The note of morbidity lends faint interest to a film that's like spending an hour and a half inside an Argos catalogue.
Bana may not be a star exactly swaddled in charisma, but what mystique he did have is disassembled as comprehensively as that coupe's innards.
Just one in a million is likely to enjoy Masayuki Miyano's laugh-free sex comedy.
movie_title: Lala Pipo: A Lot of People (Lalapipo) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Biblical parallels are laid on with crowbar delicacy.
The great strength of this documentary about the covert killing of wild dolphins in Japan is its aesthetic: artful edits, zippy music, even a few jokes. Radical stuff for an eco-documentary.
Sisters are doing it for themselves in this jolly college horror flick - if by "it" you mean horrible slaughter and softcore nudity.

If you've ever got your hands on a second-hand set of Operation, you'll know how it feels to watch the latest addition to the slum drama stable. Most parts are present and correct, but there's definitely something missing - a heart, perhaps?
Mid-August Lunch is a film of rare benevolence that treats its subjects with dignity and playfulness.
There's something irresistibly swinging, even promiscuous, about the whole affair.
movie_title: The Young Girls of Rochefort (Les Demoiselles de Rochefort) (1968)

movie_review_blurb: It's a hollow attempt at modernisation, and quickly grows dull. Watson's big dilemma - whether to quit his life with Holmes for marriage to lovely Mary has, at heart, all the depth of a Wham! song.
There is, in fact, a spark of chemistry between Heigl and Butler: it's testimony to the ineptitude that the film itself acts as such a wet blanket.
What a drag. This grabby-titled disaster flick - splashing across the pond on a tidal wave of chuckly publicity - is a damp squib.
"Even the wind has dust in its eyes," remarks Newman, at an especially weepy bit. Others may have trouble keeping them open.
The acting's superb, the premise intriguing, but it's hard to have sympathy for the heroine's stubbornness.
You can't help but feel like a bit of an eye-rolling parent, wondering if a few of them might benefit from a proper job and a light slap.
Given that it's basically one big chase, there's something awfully snoozy about this latest from Richard Jobson - a sort of cut-price, Scottish-set Hostel (a mountain bothy, maybe?).
The acting's just awful, the misogyny undeniable, but the odd flash of Shaun of the Dead-style inventiveness means you forgive it buckets.
An undeniably admirable project, but anyone who has read anything on the subject may feel they've feasted from this plate before.

There's a surprising strain of filth, too - this is much closer to Hairspray than High School Musical. The message is: burn rubber, have sex, strut about like a chicken. It's one that's hard to resist.
Even the most devout X-Files fan may have their faith tested by this snoozy addition to the franchise, which glides into cinemas with all the urgency of a Dalek with a flat battery.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Some impressively committed work from Farmiga (even when Googling "Children who kill") and a humdinger of a twist make this a rather good bad seed.
It's the seriousness with which Hardwicke treats the tale that proves its undoing.
The Squeakquel is astonishingly high-pitched, like 100 helium balloons being let off in your head. A caveat, then: dogs may pick up on subtleties I've missed.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The folksy structure both lulls and frustrates, and there's something dirgeish about the endless scenes of soul-wracking and tea-brewing. The cinematography's almost inappropriately pretty, though.
Potter proves as good on the wonky logic of parents as she does on the self-righteousness of youth.
It fizzes and sparks, but sputters too much to really catch light.

There's much to admire in Alexander Snelling's documentary about a perspiring gang of sex-starved westerners on a tantric tour of India. He clocks some genuine emotional flashpoints and shoots India with adoring vivacity.
If you've got a heart of treacle, an attention span of 15 minutes and can't afford the air fare then there are worse ways to spend a couple of hours.
Fantastically unambitious, cliched and snooze-inducing.
If Andrea Arnold met Eli Roth you might get something like this lyrically shot, energetically acted, medium grisly and totally bonkers Scottish social realism supernatural horror film.
A touch more outside perspective on such a grimy soapy saga might have both added context and leavened the watch.
Pang's film may be heavy-fisted with the satire and foggily plotted, too, despite the lengthy flashbacks, but no one could doubt his commitment to the death rattle.
When the chief baddie both stutters and slaughters puppies, you know you're in trouble.
Gerard Johnson's debut is undeniably exploitative and rather pointless, but enough red herrings get chucked into the mix to keep you interested.
This is gummy (if welcome) eco-film satire, then, but mostly just a vehicle for tent and crampon gags, and for Mangan to perfect his grating-dolt shtick.
You can't fault it for narrative ambition, nor, in fact, for curious -- one might say fishy -- watchability.
StreetDance 3D comes alive in the showcase showdowns: all stomp and backflips, so fun and infectious even the most sceptical might find themselves considering classes.
The legacy of upset is at the heart of Llosa's brilliant film -- and it's a film that wears its heart firmly on its sleeve.
movie_title: The Milk of Sorrow (La Teta Asustada) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Engaging, ruefully funny stuff.
movie_title: The Market: A Tale of Trade (Pazar: Bir Ticaret Masali) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's weirdly gripping, an authentically banal slice of life. Mumblecore must die. But maybe from its ashes will come something spikier, stranger.
The rewards of this crisp, resigned drama revisiting the horrors of the Bosnian conflict are the same as its flaws.
The spectre of suburban domestic angst hangs heavy over Lawrence Gough's horror.
Few vanity projects can be as ill-conceived as this laughless, goggingly slow Uma Thurman vehicle.
Some of the ball-spinning and torso-wiggling is genuinely impressive, and it's refreshing to see such stuff played out with the backdrop of a recognisable modern Britain.
It won't win Allen new converts, but for those of faith, it offers consolation.
There are scenes of complete brilliance, Walken is better than he's been in years, cute plot loops and grace notes.
An unshakeable tune, delivered by a director operating at rare pitch and purpose.
There's a generous pinch of very funny lines, mostly bestowed on Robbins.
Top Five is a film broad and filthy enough for multiplex appeal, but also sufficiently arch to satisfy those who fancy themselves a little more sophisticated.
It has to be said, the performances are excellent. Winslet manages emotional honesty within anachronistic confines, and Schoenaerts escapes with dignity.
Despite its sour centre, Cake's conceits quickly crumble, leaving just a half-baked pity.

It's too formulaic, too efficient at simply whisking you through and making sure you've clocked the diversity message.: without square pegs - like those played by Cumberbatch and Knightley - the world would be by far the poorer.
The first half is shot almost like a horror, all oppressive rumbling clouds and lashing of mist and shot of her back, suffocating corset laced up like a spine.
Conflicting our sympathies serves the work well. Both play and film button-push, but the substantial changes made in the transfer soften the grotesque and muddy the waters.
[Baumbach's] best, and funniest, in a decade.
It plays out like a best-of album: safe, fun, but inessential if you're already familiar with the back catalogue.
Redmayne towers: this is an astonishing, genuinely visceral performance which bears comparison with Daniel Day-Lewis in My Left Foot.
This is an effortlessly excellent film, about a horribly hard subject.
Director Deepa Mehta slathers proceedings in a haze of period whimsy - sometimes engaging, sometimes less so.
There's nourishment to be had, if you lower your expectations. But be warned: a lot of it is just watching Jon Favreau make toasties in a van.
The collateral damage involving innocent bystanders is staggering. Just mind you don't get caught in the crossfire.
Why does it work quite so well? In part, it's the Dench effect.
This works best as a portrait of a marriage, as Ushio and nimble wife Noriko rattle around their dank flat trying to keep the love strong as the water drips and the bailiffs thump.
The kids are sensitively drawn, if a little pick-and-mix in terms of their issues and ethnicities, and the whole movie breathes with kindness and intelligence.
The whole thing cost about $200m. But the best thing about it is still an old Swede in his pants.
There are emotional razors amid the wooziness.
It's gloriously strange and slippery, impossible to pin down - at once funny, uplifting, moving and deeply disquieting.
The whole thing reeks of cigars, machismo and hubris, its rhythm a relentless percussion of hairy chest pumping and big fat back slapping.
Sadly there's no denying the charge: first-degree cheese, with intent.
It's an affecting and frank take on the loneliness of faith as well as faithlessness, whose horrors come in odd contrast to the plush production values.
Quarterback scrambles forever muscle centre stage, leaving the human element scrimmaging on the sidelines.
The script persistently lets things down, and there's something irredeemably dreary about both palette and scope.

A gummy remake of the George Segal/Jane Fonda 1977 comedy, this is evidently conceived as a showcase for Carrey's waning talents, but it suffers from a mouldy premise and the slightly unsavoury underlying message.

Coogan may be game and there are plenty of nods to assorted sexploits, but this riffing on his caddish public image was done a lot more amusingly and a lot less smugly in a 10-minute skit in Jim Jarmusch's Coffee and Cigarettes.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Sadly, Kitten himself is the sort you'd be happy to string across a tennis racket, and the film never quite copes with his lethal insufferability.

Gyllenhaal can, in fact, act, so the blame must fall elsewhere for his dim performance, all topless tears and soulful voiceovers. The same goes for Peter Sarsgaard, Chris Cooper and Jamie Foxx, three good actors forced into contortions of theatrics.

Although it looks like a movie machine-tooled to ride the wave of #OscarsSoWhite backlash, its actual ambitions seem far more modest: to entertain a lot, to educate a bit and to cheerlead pretty much constantly.
This film is conceived as a showcase for its performers, and, as that, it is immaculate.
For what is, in essence, a by-numbers Disney sports flick, there's endless freshness and vivacity to Mira Nair's picture - her best in years.
Listening to Assange explain how his missives can be intercepted through overhead power cables, even those allergic can't fail but be impressed.
There are the seeds of something interesting here, but premise and talent are ill-served by crude and cliched characterisation and thudding execution ...
This should be affecting stuff, but it's consistently undercut by the massively naff aesthetic.
Ultimately Bateman's latest adds little to a debate leant pithier insight by Larkin 44 years ago.
As high-class cheese goes, Truth slips down fine.
A fluid and nippy telling of a tale that still seems strangely urgent.

The framing is erratic, logic shonky and for every cliche Abraham confounds (the call not to use any music other than that which Hank performs is admirable), there's three he clings to (barely a letter goes by without being read aloud).
No better, no worse - the synopsis serves. If you like the sound of it, you will likely like the film. And, for what it's worth, I did.
Life is lonely and cold, it says, leavened only briefly, if you're lucky. Happiness is transient. Love an anomaly. We're lucky such art as this is not.
It is worth the price of admission alone to watch this young woman tour the world, ticking off the Nigerian president over Boko Haram, holding forth with Obama and Oprah and the rest.
Watching it is like channel-surfing between Hot Fuzz, a duff early 90s Michael Douglas drama and the very schlockiest bits of Interstellar.
Everything about F&F 7 is supersized, from the actors to the running time to the scope of urban destruction.
Robin Campillo's drama is sweet and neat, as ambitious as it is gripping.
Director Sarah Gavron does well to galvanize her story with a degree of urgency: the result of swift, assured camerawork and a brilliantly understated performance by Carey Mulligan.
Such psychological candour gives Le Week-End gut punch. All three lead characters are brimful of insight.

This is Where I Leave You is totally amiable, utterly unmoving filler given a major shot in the arm by its cast, people it's simply a pleasure to watch, even with the creeping feeling they're better than this.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A remorselessly rousing attempt to do for the Scottish pub rock twins what Mamma Mia! did for Abba or Tommy for The Who.
Getting explicit sponsorship from Google is one thing; acting as an extended ad for Silicon Valley's finest strip joint does seem a bit seedy.
By the end, they are speaking with enormous precision and passion, an intellectual rigour miles superior to the work that landed them in trouble in the first place.
Weddings can often be occasions of trauma, as well as joy, and so it proves with this ensemble comedy. Well - minus the joy, that is.

The second feature from 33-year-old Katell Quillévéré, it's the sort of woozily shot, remorselessly emotional, acutely observed socio-realist soap that both confounds and confirms chick-flick prejudice.
There's the frustrating sense of ideas bubbling too low beneath the surface, of mordant jokes serving as an end rather than a means.
"How much longer do I have to stay here?" he enquires of a nurse at one point. You ask her, Jim, ask for us all.
Squint, and the title makes more sense. Shut your eyes entirely to its horrors and you'll really miss out.

It presents 26 disparate (read: in need of an editor) slices of dicing from 26 directors you've almost certainly never heard of (and indeed, the one you have - Ben Wheatley - feels tainted by association).
A squeaky door steals the show.
It is, in its way, a curious sort of auteurist cinema, in which a lone wolf (Cruise produces as well as stars) has taken an impeccably mainstream product and made it strange around him.
This is an unexpectedly winning take from one of the less splashy directors to have attempted Leonard.
By the end, you feel like a piñata on the dancefloor: empty, in bits, the victim of prolonged assault by killer pipes.
In the sober light of day, the flaws here seem to glare and screech; under the right conditions, this is cheery genre fun.
Almost every frame is astonishing.
Much Ado may be a bit of a B+ staple on the Shakespeare circuit, but Whedon - as well as improving student grades the world over - makes it feel second to none.
This is a strange and stirring film, which combines a Malick-ish concern with the emotional import of nature with a rare charm and levity. Everyday is a red letter treat.

Noah Baumbach, making his most compassionate movie since 2005's The Squid and the Whale, gives these lives the full French new wave/mid-period Woody Allen treatment, conferring charm and substance on even their most mundane interaction.
Hoffman has delivered a love letter to the elderly thesps of his adoptive country. We can forgive him its falsehoods.
Linney is terrific, and Murray, too, but he doesn't shy in showing that, in some respects, Roosevelt was as much the product of an earlier age as his buttoned-up house guests.
A tender gay romance conducted across the Gaza Strip that flips into thriller territory halfway through, to unsettling effect.
While the religious undertones are largely drowned out by the endless spumy slo-mo and board porn, there's only one way this current is flowing: towards church.
Gogglingly boring and appallingly acted: if this is east London's answer to mumblecore, god help us.
For believers, it'll be an essential tract. Such is its commitment even the sceptical can't help but be impressed through the retching.
Third Person is a work of staggering trash; an ensemble drama with the aesthetic of an in-flight magazine, but less classy writing.
It reduces a complex and extraordinary case to soap. It makes you care less, for all its heavy-breathing and cheapo coaxing.
Wells sacrifices flair to fidelity. Letts is one of the most formidable talents around today, but in handling his screenplay with such kid gloves, Wells puts a passenger in the driver's seat.
Turturro has given Allen his biggest and best on-screen turn in years: the part was written for him and it's full of scope for aimble kvetching and nimble slapstick.
[An] extremely affecting and accomplished drama ...
Reitman must be aware of the potential for innuendo, and the leap of faith such earnestness asks of its audience. He dares us to care.
Fiennes has done the right and proper thing here. He has, at 50, made a mature movie, prudent in the best possible sense.
This is highly competent catnip for the watercooler crowd.
For all the longueurs, there are still enough moments of near brilliance to sustain you through the trip.
Curtis has managed to achieve the impossible. Specifically: he has gone back to 1993 and remade Groundhog Day with a ginger Hugh Grant.
You'd expect an Alan Partridge movie to be funny. You wouldn't expect it to be a coup de cinema. And yet, in its own superficially low-brow, cheapo way, Alpha Papa is exactly that.
A fairly unmagical couple of hours at the cinema.
Coppola's dialogue is remorselessly authentic in its inanity, and this blankness runs deep in what finally feels a shallow film about shallow people.
Almost unbearable.
The sheer quantity of voiceover - or, more likely, subtitles - acts as a barrier to deep psychological immersion.
For beginners keen for a crash course, this hits every button with precision.
It's not often a brutal murder is soundtracked by a three-chord riff, but this amiable cobblers somehow gets away with it.
Smart and modulated, with attention given to the broader cultural background, and a platform offered to the rioters' detractors.
It's less affectionate homage than deeply freaky case study.
The Heat is lean, mean and completely uninterested in anything that isn't funny.
A compassionate, traumatic masterpiece, every frame amazing.
movie_title: The Enigma of Kaspar Hauser (Jeder für sich und Gott gegen alle)(Every Man for Himself and God Against All) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: An emotionally rewarding reunion tour for established fans and a taut, sharp-tongued, character-driven thriller for all, Veronica Mars makes a compelling case for its heroine's continued existence.
A meditation on the guilt, regret and shame that come with age and acquired wisdom as a pillorying of orthodox hypocrisy.
The tension builds incrementally, reaching almost unbearable heights at its dizzying climax.
It's a thoughtful and thought-provoking piece of filmmaking, which repays repeat viewing.
Set in an austere, almost abandoned Poland during the early 1960s, director Pawel Pawlikowski's first feature made in his homeland is a spare, haunting piece of minimalism.
The camera pays an almost hyperreal attention to detail, poring over certain words and touches with the obsessiveness of an infatuated teenager.
This is cinema at its most ineffable and its most potent.
Powerful, focused, nervy, lean. Certain Women is a work of art produced by a director in full control of her material. It leaves you reeling.
Toni Erdmann is as strange, delightful and dementedly funny as the hype has it. But repeat watching reveals a film that plays first as comedy, then as tragedy.
It's a hard heart that would resist Clooney's appeal to his audience to just -- for once -- be amazed.
This deft and subtle film is a fitting tribute to a man -- like him or not -- whose life deserves more than tabloid headlines.
Much of the documentary shows in gripping detail the efforts to save Europe's treasures from Hitler's clutches and the ravages of war.
Mary and Max answers affirmatively, and quite genuinely, the question: Is there someone for everyone?
Bridging many genres, Timecrimes will score high among sci-fi, horror and thriller fans, as well as the arthouse set.
Dear Zachary will break your heart -- but don't even consider missing it.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, we care little about any of the primary characters or what happens to them.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This exceedingly "fair and balanced" (in the true meaning of the phrase), densely layered scrutiny of the nation's "disappeared" knowledge warrants viewing--even repeated viewing.
This splendid late-career offering emanates fairytale enchantment with touches of magic realism.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This long-awaited final offering about the apocalyptic second sacking of Rome by an unholy pack of demons gets lost in the back alleys of '70s-era Italian horror films and unconvincing Cinecittà Studio sets.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There's still space for future indie coming-of-age stories on the order of Brick, The Graduate and Garden State, but The Wackness isn't one of them.
Should not be missed.
Nothing much happens in Still Life, its atmosphere is everything. The characters, like the half-flooded town itself, linger between the past and an unknown future.
Glass acts as a tuning fork that calibrates the significance of a compelling 20th century composer who is still going strong into the 21st.
movie_title: Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps Thriller in Manila will set the record straight.
Doctor's orders: "Buy the ticket, take the ride" with Gonzo.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Two-time Pulitzer Prize-winning [Nicholas] Krystof is the perfect subject for a bio-doc and Eric Metzger's Reporter provides a means for observing this incomparable humanitarian in action.
An engagingly philosophic approach to a mundane topic.
The fact that Jenny's flowering, her coming-of-age journey, serves as a metaphor for the times, adds another layer of richness to a peak cinematic experience.

This may be a small gem of a film but it tackles a vast, too often ignored, subject. Mid-August Lunchportrays and embraces the theme of the inevitable-and natural-passage of time with grace, dignity and humor.
Skilled direction, limpid cinematography and near-flawless acting.
Provides a framing device for the Disney creative process as well as the issue of the place of art in geo-politics.
Art & Copy possesses enough classy artistry, hip invention, and big-idea philosophy to launch itself into the documentary stratosphere--where it belongs.
Hirokazu Kore-Eda's latest effort, further entrenches my belief he should be considered one of Japan's living treasures.
As tragic as his death was, the film celebrates the indomitable spirit, dignity and resilience of Sergio Vieira de Mello.
The film's comic tone and biting dialogue tempers the awareness that these vignettes symbolize deeper and more dangerous issues.

Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country reignites the gut-wrenching ethos of early cinema verite as it reaffirms the power of "film truth" and the imperative for freedom of speech as a fundamental human right.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Forbidden Lie$, a Möbius strip of a documentary, weaves in and out of its protagonist's story to the point of exhaustion -- but the ride is thrilling and intermittently jaw-dropping.
Surpasses any mockumentary you've ever seen.

This credible and moving portrayal of a man with Asperger's Syndrome, whose passion for science and his love for a woman help him in his struggle to achieve a meaningful relationship, should find an appreciative audience.

Barthe's potential as an imaginative and intellectual writer and a director with a distinctive visual style displays more than promise in Cold Souls, her debut feature, it exhibits a self-assurance and a brilliance and should not be missed.
The documentary is achingly confusing and true in a way we often associate with fiction.
For even the little ones in the audience, Doug's First Movie will feel long and drawn out.
Madame Sousatzka is a perfect one-woman show, and this show belongs to its star, Shirley MacLaine.

It's good to have veteran and able actor Sidney Poitier back on the screen again, and his contribution to Shoot to Kill helps make this action-thriller set in the mountain wilds of the Northwest a slick and satisfying film.
There could not have been four more perfect roles for the likes of Midler and Tomlin; they play these flip-side characterizations with perfect wit and trascend every cliche.
This is strictly a Fox-fan picture.
It pays handsomely to hang on tight and enjoy the ride. There's always some surprises when Richard Pryor takes the stage.
Above the Law has enough off-beat updates on the cops-and-robbers theme to at least make the film visually interesting most of the time.
The direction is fast-paced, the characters are vulnerable and sympathetic and even the bad guys have their moments.
There's so much energy in this satire, that you can't help laughing at its bawdy charm. Clumsy, irreverent, adolescent, yes. And often very funny.
It's simply so cute, it's hard to resist and the supporting cast -- especially D'Angelo and Shawn -- bring it all to wonderful life.

The Fourth Protocol not only does what a good spy movie should do, twist and turn through treachery and deceit to the inevitable surprising conclusion, it also does what any good movie should do, entertain by telling a good story well.
It's a ditzy comedy that also manages to make a good point about the cruel choices people are forced to make.
While E.T. had tears to spare for everyone in the family, Harry and the Hendersons is strictly for the kids.

The conflict may be familiar, but Stone brings the mystery of Wall Street's heros and villains, its big-stakes players and two-bit salesmen into sharp focus. It's a look that is both exhilarating and astounding.
Bat 21 belongs to Hackman and Glover, and director Markle has the good sense to let these two veterans take over the show.

Bill presents his story of 5 Corners with a delicate mix of passion and humor, satire and devotion. It's the story of a time in America that became a crossroads for a generation, as well as for a unique neighborhood called 5 Corners.
Sidney Poitier, 10 years absent from the screen, is now back with a vengeance.
There's no denying Mailer is a man with vision, and the eloquence to describe it. It's just that the vision is so troubling, so mean and raw and frightening.

It shouldn't work, this movie about reincarnation, true love and angels. It ignores all logic in favor of allusion, trick photography and the earnest work of its hard-working stars: Timothy Hutton, Kelly McGillis, Maureen Stapleton. But work it does.
Taking the best of recent sci-fi, action and cop films, this movie adds a new twist, throws in a demonic dog and comes up with some entertaining -- and scary -- fare.
Breathtakingly beautiful, but a mess.
Ironweed makes the sadness seem isolated and dangerous and unreal; it only exists where the bums live, it doesn't reach into the lives of good families.
Danny DeVito directs and stars in this funny, offbeat homage to Alfred Hitchcock thrillers, but it's co-star Billy Crystal who brings all the elements together

Matewan is an earnest and sympathetic look at both the universal tragedy of the exploitation of workers and the specific tragedy of the struggle of the Matewan townspeople to find some dignity in a harsh existence.
It's a sweet, lyrical movie with plenty of musical nostalgia. But more importantly, Dirty Dancing has an uplifting message of hope that can be found only in the dreams of the young.
The good intentions seem frivolous and what starts out to be a study of a senseless violence in Northern Ireland ends in a senseless study of troubled personalities.
Directed by 'Robert Zemeckis, Who Framed Roger Rabbit is a murder mystery turned on its (very long rabbit) ears, and a spirited tribute to the magic of animation and laughter.
The film barrels along with a bumbling zeal, but it's comedy at its most predictable.

Short's physical humor is exuberant and fun to watch, and Dennis Quaid, playing the pilot of the miniature ship that voyages through Short, puts in a good performance as the hot-shot with the "right stuff."
Nuts never equals the sum of its parts. There's never a doubt the moxie lady-of-the-night at the center of the film is anything but sane, and it takes a good deal of the edge off the movie.
Everybody's All-American only looks and sounds great, making the most of the music and fashions from 1957 to 1987. Its soul is paper-thin.
Jamie may be less articulate and inspired than Holden Caulfield, but he seems as genuine a spokesman for his time.
The world may not need yet another swashbuckling epic adventure, but one with so much heart and soul and fantasy surely is a welcome addition.
Empire of the Sun is a breathtaking movie in its scope and energy. It's just that, true to its childlike quality, this film is just a little too over-anxious to get its point across.

It's hard to fault a story so poignant and still so relevant. But this tale of lost souls deserved exactly the right setting, one that could have provided the intimacy needed to illustrate a sad, yet hopeful, message.

Though Punchline defies the Hollywood penchant for producing either pure comedy or straight drama, its view of those with the guts to stand before an audience and dare them to laugh is oddly uplifting.

What makes this all work, of course, is Hanks himself, who brings remarkable authenticity and simplicity to the role. He makes being a kid seem as wonderful as it was, and as scary and as confusing too.
There is nothing at all happening in Tequila Sunrise but a lot of vacuous drama about the loyalty between two high school buddies and the luminous beauty who must decide between them.
It is the grandeur of the boy king and his unreal opulent world that is best remembered, splendid and isolated, and at last, because of its loneliness, sad.
Full Metal Jacket, produced, directed and co-written by Stanley Kubrick, is not an easy film to watch, but from the first frame to the last, it is a riveting one.
This sendup by director Mel Brooks incorporates the silliest aspects of all the major space adventures of the last decade, and the whole is a hilarious combination of its parts.
Vibes stumbles and fumbles and misfires sure-fire one-liners and zany situations; it ends up being both a confused and confusing jumble of half-witted comedy and ridiculous drama.
No matter what your thoughts are of the plot and its execution, the picture of Arnold Schwarzenegger and Danny DeVito dressed up in identical linen suits and shades will keep you laughing.
Like a nightmare, it's the surreal feeling of the movie that stays with you. Unfortunately it is also like a nightmare in that there's little of the movie you care to remember.
Set against a Cajun background, the movie is a bird's-eye view of a little-known culture operating within a totally familiar urban context. The effect is exhilarating.

This bittersweet love story is set against the world of network news and writer-producer-director James Brooks fills his satire with some lovable heros and villains -- and characters that don't quite fit into either category.
Married to the Mob is full of promise, but goes nowhere, apparently satisfied enough with being avant-garde and hip.

The courtroom scenes are filled with wit and drama, lacking in any cliche and false emotion. If the movie had applied the same techniques it used in these scenes to the rest of the movie, it would have helped immensely.
Mostly, Rambo III is one breathtaking sequence after another, with an absolutely mind-boggling scene with Rambo removing a spike from his side, and then sealing the wound with flaming gunpowder.
Molly Ringwald and Robert Downey Jr. head the unusually talented cast of characters assembled for this small but taut film.
What makes Midnight Run so remarkable are its principals, and the supporting cast that keep the audience titillated, laughing and excited for the film's entire 128 minute-running time.
The comedian proves himself -- again -- as an unfailing mimic with astounding energy.
There didn't seem to be anything special in the unraveling of the murder plots in The Dead Pool, but for what it lacked in suspense, Dirty Harry and company made up in talent and wit.
Jewison's point seems to be that love may not be perfect, but it can be sweet fun.

Reynolds and Turner turn in nice work as the hard-boiled couple who love to hate one another... Reeve is the surprise in this movie, turning his character into a wonderful caricature of a 1988 self-absorbed yuppie businessman.
A dreary television-movie-of-the-week drama, far beneath the considerable talents of the mostly gifted cast.

While there's enough blood and guts to satisfy the most avid cop-film fan, this version is played for as many laughs as gasps. Robocop has the same slapstick look at violence that made Mad Max so quirky and appealing.
When the movie shows the brothers picking their dangerous path as much from selfishness and arrogance as from desparation, the film has a gritty, believable realism.
Cocktail is so steeped in corn, the drama seems comedic and the comedy is about as funny as a hangover.
Martin Scorsese's most provocative film also turns out to be uncomfortably slow-paced and sluggish.
The antics alone are fun to watch, but the dialogue is priceless, and there's never been such a hilarious blend of American and British humor.

Writer-director Ron Shelton tells a wonderful story of how a veteran ballplayer and up-and-comer collide in the world of the minor leagues, and how they are loved by a baseball groupie who's also a philosopher and poet.
Chevy Chase does the best comedic acting of his movie career in this off-beat satire of exquisite rural living.
Like Father, Like Son manages to have a heart along with a sense of humor.
Coming to America, starring Eddie Murphy and directed by John Landis, takes a lame idea and some very talented comedic actors and manages to avoid a complete disaster. But just barely.
The Princess Bride is a worthy descendant to the Fractured Fairytales of yore. The characters -- both real and imaginary -- give every frame of The Princess Bride its own magic mirth.
Rent-a-Cop barely packs five bucks worth of action, suspense and romance.
It's a film about ordinary people put in unordinary circumstances pressed to extraordinary levels, and the film itself becomes extraordinary by the effort.
Subtitled The Quest for Peace, this Superman sequel should have been called the The Quest for a Plot.
movie_title: Superman IV: The Quest for Peace (1987)

movie_review_blurb: The strength of the film is that of the novel: an intoxicating brew of irresistable characters.
It will take most Americans more than just a little effort to believe the Hollywood of this movie is the same place that eventually produced Rambo II.
The update carries only a surface resemblance to its television ancestor; the rest is more reminiscent of the comic-book world of Batman, Robin and Superman.
The film sets out to be large, dramatic and powerful -- as well as endearing -- and misses on every point.
Melanie Griffith and Sigourney Weaver steal the show with their good guy-bad guy roles.
Things Change is like the careful telling of a sly and spirited joke. Everything builds slowly, and the telling is as important as the punch line.
The film is all Williams; he has a field day with this character and this country and this period in history, with all its horror -- and comedy.
[Hughes] proves he also can handle life on the other side of graduation.

Dead Ringers may be a beautifully structured and well-acted movie, but it certainly's isn't an easy film to watch. Still, if you like horror movies, this one will keep you on the edge of your seat, albeit squirming every minute.
It's a film about ordinary people put in unordinary circumstances pressed to extraordinary levels, and the film itself becomes extraordinary by the effort.
Stealing Home packs a lot of emotional wallops, but more often than not, the punches miss the mark.

There are the requisite chase seens, the ingenious murder weapons, the evil propogators of greed andhate. And somehow they don't bury you. In the end, it's the wit and heart of Alien Nation that win you over.
A little wisecracking might have done this movie a world of good.
Though not perfect, Extreme Prejudice provides a steely Nick Nolte as the white hat hero and for those who pine for the days when Westerns were king, the film is worth seeing.

There are pratfalls aplenty and enough animal antics to elicit a few giggles, but Willis and Basinger never quite bring the necessary spark to the roles and the film disappears as fast as a bag of popcorn.
A non-stop chase movie filled with so much good humor it's like an all-expense paid trip to another planet.
Levinson has an unerring eye for the trappings of the period, and like Diner, the supporting characters add a realism that is often forgotten in the 'big movie' mentality of the 80s.
It is both drama at its most entertaining -- and an enlightening peronal lesson in the history of America's involvement in Cambodia during the Vietnam era.

For want of a timeless message on the horrors of war, Coppola does indeed tell a compelling story of one man's battle on the homefront. Caan gives a stunning performance after a five-year absence from the movie screen.
Wonderfully fast and action-packed.
Primarily, this moody film is a series of snapshots of a rural tobacco farming community in North Carolina that just begs for some cool rationale.
Taut screenwriting (David Mamet) and a superb cast -- including a prize-winning performance by Sean Connery as the veteran Chicago cop -- help make 'The Untouchables' a classic.
This big, overblown comedy starring Dustin Hoffman and Warren Beatty is thoroughly likable despite all the hype.
This quirky tale of power, love and loneliness can't help but entertain with its lush photography (by Vimos Zsigmond) and heavenly cast.

Sean Penn and Robert Duvall play a mismatched team of cops on a special anti-gang task force on the Los Angeles Police Department. Their characters' growth makes this movie much more than a sensational look at street gangs, which it most certainly is.

The story may be too black for many looking for a light comedy, or entertainment-escape. But it's a film that's haunting in the way it unravels the love at the core of two brothers who discover each other.

It is a cast perfectly blended to this story of human foibles and eternal love. And best of all, each actor, whether their part is large or small, seems to genuinely enjoy the high-jinks they are helping create.
At heart, The Believers is a remake of Rosemary's Baby with none of the wit and twice as much gore.
Midler's singing is the only pleasant part of the film. The rest of it you've seen and heard before -- and better.

It would be hard to improve upon the classic, after all, and Scrooged not only sticks to the Dickens plot, but makes it believable as a modern fable. But the more difficult part of Scrooged is its modernization, the colorization of Dickens, if you will.
Dalton's Bond brings the British spy much closer to the head and heart of a real character.

Roxanne has a way of making you feel good even though you know it may be the corniest movie you've seen. Filled with romance, from its plot to the scenery, Roxanne makes no apologies for its sweet fervor.
This is a movie about music and it is the Valens sound, a unique blending of Latin rhythm and rock beat, that prevents La Bamba from being just another example of Hollywood hero worship.
Everything about School Daze is frantic, and the energy is addictive.
Lady in White, written and directed by Frank LaLoggia, manages to combine the eery and ordinary in a fanciful and melancholy ghost tale.
Dare to be Wild is a visual feast, but perhaps a bit too epic for this viewer.

The cast are given the space to make the most of each scene, which they do ably. They are captured along the way by Piers McGrail's captivating cinematography, along with the vast and expansive scenery.
It is fitting that the work of Eileen Gray should be reintroduced and revisited in so rich a fashion.
It has a certain amount of charm, mostly thanks to the cast, but ultimately A Hologram for the King is a little underwhelming.
Crump's film documents this historical artistic movement, while also raising greater questions about the nature of art itself.
movie_title: Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Comedy and drama are nicely balanced in this mostly true tale.
This fun family film, based on Carl Hiaasen's Newbery award-winning book of the same name, has a strong ecological message served with a big helping of giggle-inducing sight gags.
Zac Efron will probably break out of the heartthrob mold eventually, but Charlie St. Cloud is not going to be the one to do it for him.
The last time I saw a 3-D movie in a movie theater I got the glasses from a cereal box. Suffice it to say, the technology has advanced a bit, and the filmmakers use it to impressive effect.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With an adventure-fantasy, a certain amount of creative license is to be expected -- even encouraged -- but this third installment of the Mummy franchise is nearly swamped by distracting lapses in logic.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Although I ultimately enjoyed it, I left wishing the filmmakers had taken better advantage of this chemistry.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Not surprisingly, what's right about Righteous Kill begins and ends with Robert DeNiro and Al Pacino.
It's the individual story, fleshed out by Philip Railsback's intelligent script, that makes the audience care.
Satisfying for the heart, definitely, but the head is left wanting.
As silly as it is, there's a relentless energy bursting from every aspect of High School Musical 3.

What I couldn't predict was how much I would enjoy the simple pleasures of a warm, witty, well-written story -- especially when it is told with the state-of-the-art computer animation that is easy to take for granted in these techno-savvy days.
Despite its flaws, Bedtime Stories has the charming, giggly spirit of an imaginative toddler.
Hotel for Dogs reminds me -- in a good way -- of the Disney live-action classics of the '60s.
Has enough fresh charm to make up for the lack of originality.
Jones' narration is both warm and authoritative. If Mufasa can't make kids care about the Earth, it might be a lost cause.

Unfortunately, nothing else in Is Anybody There? quite equals the main performances. There are nice moments throughout, but it meanders a bit. We learn a little about the other residents, but not enough to invest emotionally.
Murphy's controlled mania and the chemistry he has with Yara Shahidi, who plays his daughter, make this well-worn narrative path seem fresher than it is.
What happens when Disney meets Jerry Bruckheimer? You get a whole new kind of rodent, but not necessarily a better one.
In an attempt to ride the comic coattails of the Judd Apatow comedies, The Ugly Truth is full of crude and profane language, but it comes across as awkwardly inappropriate rather than edgy.
Delicate and understated performances by Rose Byrne -- and especially a remarkable Hugh Dancy as the quirky Asberger's sufferer -- give the unlikely romance a quiet, realistic tone.
Zellweger does a nice job keeping her character more sympathetic than pathetic, as the realization that she is no longer an ingénue lets her become something more.
Amelia Earhart is known for being an aviation pioneer and, ultimately, a mystery, but the new biopic with Hilary Swank as the groundbreaking pilot has added a surprising new word to the mix: boring.
It is interesting to see Jackson in a world created to his specifications after years of only seeing him in the "real" world he never quite fit into.
Long after the race of the characters is (hopefully) no longer a novelty, it's the quality of The Princess and the Frog that will keep audiences charmed.
Despite the considerable charms of stars Kristen Bell and Josh Duhamel, When in Rome doesn't quite work, in either the love or laughter departments.
Hopkins is in his element and, as usual, incredibly fun to watch. He's a bit heftier than Hannibal Lecter, but the dangerous twinkle is still there.

The commercials make it seem like a typical angst-filled college romance and, in large part, it is. But in the end, it becomes something more, but describing exactly what would do a disservice to its often subtly crafted story.

You'd expect a lot of blood with a story where organs are removed on the fly, but director Miguel Sapochnik seems to revel in the gore and, at times, the intertwining of sex and "surgery" has an uncomfortably pornographic feel.
Imaginatively done, full of peril, surprise and even humor.
Although the actors do their level best, there are no surprises offered and no romance/pregnancy/childbirth cliché unused. And yet, I have to admit, the movie was enjoyable.
Shrek Forever After ends (presumably) the Shrek saga on an up note, thanks to a fresh take on a classic plot twist.
Although the movie repeatedly gives glossed lip service to feminism, it actually gives detractors who said the series perpetrated shallow female stereotypes a huge, glittery, indefensible target.
A sequel that's as good -- and, in some ways, better -- than the charmingly fluffy 2005 original.
The movie, like its stars, is not without its charm. It just would have been nice to be delighted by an unexpected flash of humor or feel the slightest bit of suspense about the resolution.
The witless, cliché-ridden script -- the effort of a total of five writers -- doesn't do [Allen] any favors.
It's not as funny or original as Knocked Up, but it has its moments.
Easy A is really more of a B+. But even with the quibbles, a teen comedy this original deserves high marks.
Quote not available.
While there is something undeniably enjoyable about watching someone likable enjoy themselves, it's not enough to make a good movie.
Nanny McPhee is a rare family film that manages to be funny without being gross, and heartwarming without being cloying.
It's a harmless diversion that should keep kids amused and parents relaxed.
... makes a powerful impression.
The movie equivalent of the munchies that enthrall its characters -- not much substance, but a lot of fun.
It's a promising concept, and director Ivan Reitman and writer Don Payne come up with a lot of snappy lines and funny sight gags, but the pieces never quite mesh into a satisfying comedic whole.
In the end, John Tucker is a lot like high school: I'll look back on it with a smile, but I'm glad it's behind me.
Maybe if the plot was more engaging I wouldn't have been so distracted, but Barnyard was pretty disappointing.
Worms has a relaxed, naturalistic quality that allows the cast's child actors to shine.

What elevates Season is the wit and enthusiasm of its voice actors -- particularly Kutcher and Sinise. They both sound like they're having a fantastic time, and it's hard not to be swept along with them.
While the songs and animation occasionally slow down the action a bit, they join nicely with the movie's understated humor to painlessly deliver its ecological lessons.
Freedom Writers manages to strike some fresh chords without playing its audience.
Most ridiculous is that, at the end of the movie, which up until then was basically a violent video game with aspirations, Carnahan turns Aces into a thumpingly heavy-handed morality play.
Bridge to Terabithia blew me -- and my cynicism -- away. Even though I was drawn in from the beginning, I kept waiting for Terabithia to let me down, but it never did.
Premonition is a thriller almost completely without thrills, with a puzzler that raises questions it never bothers to answer.
An above-average movie elevated partly by the performances of two acting powerhouses, but mostly by the chemistry created by their pairing.
I found myself entertained, engaged and, occasionally, pleasantly surprised.
The charm of the actors, the unabashedly romantic goofiness and the clever winks at classic Disney set pieces make the movie not only kid-friendly but a guilty pleasure for adults as well.
Mostly amusing and good-natured, occasionally hysterical, and actually manages to sneak in a subtle lesson about nature.
The movie is full of fun moments with classic fairytale characters and props (poison apple, magic mirror, etc.) woven into modern life.
As depressing as the first two-thirds of the film is, the last third is surprisingly empowering and hopeful.
While the broad strokes are predictable, the fine details of Definitely, Maybe are a near-constant stream of small, albeit lightweight, delights.
Stardust includes a troupe of familiar faces in small, witty parts, plus some genuinely original touches, but, despite being virtually busting with magic, isn't as magical as it should be.
Singularly unoriginal, full of clichÃ (C)s and tough-neighborhood set pieces tied together with GoodFellas-style voice-over narration.
[Nancy Drew's] spunky resourcefulness is given an exaggerated, tongue-in-cheek treatment by director/co-writer Andrew Fleming. But it's all done with affection and respect.
Fresh, funny and full of laid-back charm.
[Writer-director Shelly's] characters are at the same time comfortably familiar and unpredictable. Her script is big-hearted and life-embracing, but still unsentimental.
What's really irritating about Perfect Stranger is not how bad it is, but how close it came to being good.
Cheadle and Sandler are not names I would have expected to hear together as an effective buddy-picture pairing, but they work.
Leads right back to the usual sitcom destination.

The Disney feel that makes it safe for the whole family also probably robs it of some of the more complex shading ... But considering how rare intelligent family-friendly movies are, it's a worthy sacrifice.
I won't bother to catalog the movie's lapses in logic. Actually, it's misleading to call them lapses, because I'm hard-pressed to recall any logic to lapse from.

Clebrates the studio's classic storytelling history while serving up an exciting modern adventure, full of heart and humor, beautiful computer-generated animation, lots of twists -- and yes, a princess.
While things occasionally get a bit too quirky, the young leads - Nick Robinson, Gabriel Basso and Moises Arias - make it work.
A thoroughly delightful, impressively animated, summer movie with plenty of laughs, a gentle wit and a surprisingly nuanced range of life lessons.
It boasts two beautiful performances from Terence Stamp and Vanessa Redgrave.
While its broad strokes don't break any new ground, its surprise and charm are in the small details and individual performances.
The impact is in the suggested and the unseen, rather than the gory and grotesque - just as it is like the best classic horror films.
Anyone who has seen NPH host the Tonys or the Emmys may wonder if there is nothing the actor can't do. Well, he can't make his thankless role as straight man to tiny blue cartoons work.
All in all, less-than-stellar Disney is still above-average entertainment, and "Planes" undoubtedly will keep the little fliers amused - even while their parents put their brains on autopilot.
As a moviegoer, I am not against car chases, but I generally like some movie wrapped around them.
In the end, "Don Jon" offers the promise of progress without pat answers. It also offers the promise of the future work of an undeniably talented actor-turned-director.
Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs 2 captures the goofy fun of the first course, while offering some completely original giggles.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Warts and all, the movie definitely succeeds in engaging its audience.
While what may be the first-ever major Thanksgiving-themed animated feature is fun for kids and witty enough for some adult giggles, I was slightly underwhelmed.
In addition to its sharp/sweet dialogue, the movie's success rests with the radiant dorkiness of leads Gleeson and McAdams, as well as the quirky supporting cast.
If the movie had embraced its farcical side, I would have been happy to roll with it. But every time it tried to be serious, it revealed lapses of logic that I couldn't get past.
Full of clever songs, genuine laughs and thrills, plenty of heart and just a touch of romance, [Frozen] definitely holds its own with the likes of The Little Mermaid and Beauty and the Beast.
Fun, but ultimately not really satisfying.
Both too much and not enough.

The basic elements are very much like "The Bodyguard" and countless dangerous-rise-to-fame movies. The originality lies in the details, up-to-date themes and the strong performances of the relatively young lead actors.
Maybe if Reitman was making this point with a single, layered story, my heart could have been engaged even as my head was saying, "No kidding."

Saying that the visuals outshine the story in an animated feature is not usually good news, but when the animation is as original and stunning as that in "The Book of Life," the result is well worth seeing.

While the relatively leisurely pace of a novel offers readers the time to appreciate each character's story, the film is so rushed that only Bateman's character comes close to being satisfyingly explored.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: For someone who once played James Bond, you'd think Pierce Brosnan would have better instincts when choosing another spy thriller.
The movie offers no colorful villains, no sharp turns or surprises, little drama, chuckles instead of laughs, and a somewhat pokey and predictable plot. And I enjoyed every minute of it.
"Kon-Tiki" has a grand, old-fashioned feel - a man-against-nature adventure that feels like it was made in - not just set in - the optimistic post-World War II era.
There are some funny moments, but the former "Bad Teacher" co-stars are surprisingly chemistry-free.
"How to Train Your Dragon 2" succeeds because it builds on, but doesn't try to replicate, the magic of the first movie.
Fleshing out one of Disney's quintessential villains is an intriguing idea. But, while "Maleficent" teases at the premise's potential, it never quite sustains the magic.
Many scenes in "Neighbors" are genuinely funny; others are really gross. Many are both. But in the end, the movie's tone and humor are pretty uneven.
I don't have much time to write this review, because after seeing "Oculus" I need to cover every mirror in the house before I go to bed.
Doesn't quite capture the surprise magic of the last effort, but it's still a lot of fun.
The action is, as advertised, nonstop, and well-paced throughout. There are a number of exciting action sequences, and the suspense never flags.
"Think Like a Man Too" is even less substantial than the original, but funnier in a manic, glitzy way befitting its Vegas setting.
It's the toll that the scandal took on Plame's marriage and family, as well as the collateral damage to Plame's CIA contacts, that gives "Fair Game" its pulse.
The movie belongs to Tom Hardy.
Like its hero - voiced with comic frustration by Nicolas Cage - "The Croods" is simple and funny, if not too complex, and completely family-friendly and fun.
The performances are not helped much by the script or the movie's muddy palette, which gives everything the look and sound of a '70s movie of the week.
Sitting in the theater, my affection was definitely on-again, off-again at best. But in the end, the good times, which were fantastic, won me over.
The musical numbers offer some of the strongest moments in "Country Strong." The story's offstage dramas, however, are like a country song with every other verse removed.
"Beastly" is not the best or the worst teen movie I've ever seen, but given the talented cast (especially Harris), I would have loved to see them tackle a more realistic reboot.
It's Verbinski's trust in the audience to get his jokes and pop-culture references that makes "Rango" such an engaging ride.
Succeeds both as a sci-fi adventure and as a familial love story.
"Hop" is stuffed with humorous moments and clever gags.
Unfortunately, although it asks some interesting questions, it's hampered by annoying and downright unlikable characters.
"Kung Fu Panda 2" is still a lot of fun. But like so many sequels, it's not quite No. 1.
I know I probably shouldn't have liked it as much as I did, but I have to admit I enjoyed its colorful, chaotic goofiness.
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There is a lot to like about "Cars 2." The 3-D animation is sumptuous, the action sequences are exciting. It manages to be witty enough to engage adults while being 100% kid-friendly.
Well-meaning, sort of sweet, but can't really get it together: That describes both Kevin James' character and his new movie, "Zookeeper."
Rather than a mind-blowing movie experience, "Pooh" is a cinematic snuggle.
Like its slacker hero, "30 Minutes or Less" turns out surprisingly well despite a lot of questionable choices.
[It] can't exactly be called a pleasure of any kind, but it is quietly compelling, building the tension as methodically as its characters chip away at the medical puzzle.
Takes the classic "The Bicycle Thief" and reinvents it for today with quiet, powerful effect.
I'm guessing more than a few moviegoers will lace up their hiking boots for their own pilgrimage.
"Rise of the Guardians" gives classic holiday heavyweights a fresh and funny new spin, but it's the delightful fleshing out of the fantastical "B team" that really makes the movie click.

Consistently playful, often delightful and frequently funny.

movie_review_blurb: What is entirely new about The Villainess is that it marries its revenge scenario to a melodrama of maternal sacrifice, with the film's terrific star, Kim Ok-bin, suffering more than Joan Crawford ever did.

An entertaining, well-constructed spy story (though not as satisfying as the first film -- perhaps because it's not as simple).

It's a bit like a Jean-Pierre Jeunet film. It's very kooky...after a while I just gave in so I didn't have to sit through the 102 minute runtime crying quietly into my complimentary chocolate bar. I don't know if that's a good or bad thing.

if it wasn't for the distractingly wall-to-wall indie soundtrack... and mildly cop-out ending, I'd be pushing this straight to the top end of our Best of 2010 list.

Unfortunately, as is so often the case, it all went downhill in the last half hour.

movie_review_blurb: Weighed down by a reverence to its true-life source material and desperate to make both a political and personal statement, it seems constantly unable to decide what it wants to say.
