This does pretty much what it says on the tin, though the interactive "3D" element does introduce a twist of sorts.

Purportedly offering a slice of cultural history, this documentary is basically a big plug for fancy-schmancy "neo-burlesque" stripper Immodesty Blaize. Shameless stuff and about as sexy as a poke in the groin with a blunt stick.
The first time we see heads roll it's entertaining. The second time it's boring. The eighth time...
Essential viewing for people fascinated by the Nineties music scene of the Nineties. Pop history is written by musicians who get on with journalists. Watch and learn how it's done.
movie_title: Blur: No Distance Left to Run (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Boys Are Back is frightened of being frightening and, as a result, has no sense of momentum.
As rowdy, democratic and open-ended as a Robert Altman saga, Brothers breathes life into the clichés surrounding traumatised vets.
As the last shot lingers, you long to find out what happens next.
Departure's cynicism, ironically, is what makes the optimism of its last act so moving.
This interminable, Soho-based gay relationship drama is especially marred by the dire acting of Luke de Woolfson, who plays a bad actor.
If Paranormal Activity is not quite as scary as the publicity would have us believe, it is at least witty, thought-provoking and -in a woozy, stark sort of way - beautiful.

Stiller has an ear for mainstream projects that keep a few steps ahead of the crowd, like Meet the Parents and Tropic Thunder. Escape 2 Africa is tame by comparison but it never treats us like dumb animals.

The more the film insists that we see Verona and Burt as perfect, the more smug and unreal they appear. The messy mix of twee maundering and frat-boy slapstick might work if one thing were added: a caption at the end that read: "... and then Burt woke up"
Fish Tank feels electrifyingly bold. And yet, taken as a whole, it's frustrating.
In common with so many Polish directors, Andrezej Jakimowski is obsessed with the peculiar magic of fate and coincidence but unlike Kieslowski, say, he avoids grandly ecstatic/gloomy set-pieces.
It's a black comedy, full of great lines and it deserves to be a mainstream hit. What a shame that it's often unnecessarily graphic.
Despite the group's many successes, self-pitying tears are rarely far from their eyes. It's fascinating stuff and unfathomably bleak.
Vincent Cassel is superb in the lead, craggily handsome, steely and volatile.
It's all a bit silly. There are lots of chases, curses, kisses and the odd fancy gadget.
It was made 33 years ago but Nagisa Oshima's doomed lust classic doesn't look in the least bit dusty. Quite the opposite.
movie_title: In the Realm of the Senses (1976)

movie_review_blurb: It's a film that is more ambitious than Knocked Up or The 40-Year Virgin and yet somehow more frustrating, too.
[Almodovar] frames with the greatest passion and, here, with muse Penélope Cruz dominating a story of erotic obsession, he surpasses himself.
Julie & Julia is a very American kind of money-spinner. Crucially, though, it is never dumb.
Happily, it's not only a return to form for the one-time Mormon and agent provocateur, it also offers Samuel L Jackson his first decent part in years.

Julia, by and large, is a tale of desperate opportunists, fugitive souls who survive by living on their wits, taking risks and making it up as they go along. It sometimes feels that a similar person is behind the camera as well as in front of it.
Once Lombard starts throwing stilettos, you know it's time to get off the line.
This ultra-hyped adaptation of the ultra-successful Helen Fielding novel sends you out with a smile on your face.
Ironically, what jeopardises the transaction is Ryan.

Does it matter that every time Jolie's offscreen the film wilts a little? Ryder should be perfect as the bright spark; her lines are sharp as a knife. There's a gap, however, between what we hear and what we see.
Sadly, Sheen doesn't even look profound. Like a zombie who's spent too much time in the gym, he blunders heavily from one stunt to the next, his pursed lips conveying nothing more than pique.
Much of the best dialogue, you suspect, was improvised by Tucker and Chan, who seem truly taken with each other and make a delightful, ordinary-extraordinary pair.
What saves the film from abomination is the basketball.
If you cut the beatings, you wouldn't be left with much.
The use of Plowright as a middle-aged frump wanting to get in on the sexy action is deeply patronizing.
Equally unengaging are hero Tim (Davidson), the wimpish buppie who loves her, and his male buddies, who provide the requisite quota of chauvinism.
Broomfield has great visual style, exposing-Britain's ugliness and beauty at every turn.
Myers exploits every vicious, self-hating line that comes his way.
And so we leave the cinema happy, our heads full of Gareth and gangsters-at-sea. Context, of course, is all.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Vermeer's great gift as an artist was to imbue ordinary life with a sense of mystery. Alas poor Webber. The immaculate consummation witnessed here idles in a middlebrow limbo, neither earthy nor divine.
With so much to say, Hanson's movie is too frenetic.
In its eagerness to give voice to the overshadowed daughter, the film never allows the mother to live.
The Talented Mr. Ripley is worth more than a peep.
The irony is that LaBute (revising a screenplay by Laura Jones) has added syrup to the romances and drained out the danger.
Both Winfrey and Demme get a lot wrong.
You've Got Mail has much in common with Sleepless in Seattle but ultimately pales by comparison.
This is a film with all the itchily sweet passion of a Shangri-Las anthem, cranked up to full volume.
Nothing much about Mike Judge's creation has changed.
Armored is based on a first-time script which, thanks to a bit of industry hype, became the subject of a bidding war among the studios. Sony won the day. Guys, you were robbed.
I imagine someone like Gareth from The Office watching it, a big grin on his face, a box of tissues by his side.
It's easily the best of the trilogy and, for my money, one of the most enjoyable films of the decade.
Director Djamshed Usmonov frames his story beautifully.
movie_title: To Get to Heaven, First You Have to Die (Bihisht faqat baroi murdagon) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The performances are excellent - low-key and nuanced - but the set-up is so contrived that you never feel involved for long.
Yet for all the imperfections, Flawless is a film you find yourself rooting for. Heists involving a keen sense of history are pleasant to stumble across.
Año Uña feels like a calling card from a promising talent - but, as with a summer romance, it's not built to last.
Vince Vaughn and Reese Witherspoon play the leads. Do they convince as lawyers or lovers? No. Do they convince as space aliens trying to infiltrate the human race? Yes.
Sometimes the grimness and grandeur gel; sometimes they just add up to pompous soaps.
It feels like a spoof, yet this documentary, which follows the fortunes of a monumentally rubbish Iraqi band called Acrassicauda, is for real.

RocknRolla did not leave me wanting more (the last shot promises a sequel is on its way). Still, its confidence is impressive. London's property bubble may have burst but Ritchie's career is definitely on the rise.

In fact, Lopez deserves praise for pushing this project. The recently deceased Puchi (who helped generate the script and pushed for Lopez to play her) is not the kind of character you see on screen every day.

Plays like an unravelling of the Eighties comedy hit Trading Places. Instead of a smart-Alec street hustler who turns the tables on his seemingly benign patrons, we have a smart saint who simply wants to join the club.
He has tried to make Georgiana's quest for independence - her attempt to gain power via the media and the Whigs - just as gritty. Against the odds, he mostly succeeds.
A good-looking, sophisticated, if somewhat pointless addition to the slasher-horror genre.
Dude, the film so totally happens to be great.
French director Mathieu Kassovitz was once touted as the next Scorsese, thanks to his gritty debut, La Haine. Alas, this action-adventure epic suggests he has settled for being a Hollywood wannabe.
A week is a long time in cinema. Last Friday saw Branagh being all but written off thanks to the ludicrous Sleuth. This week, he's hitting the high notes.
The film's target audience - dummies everywhere - will be blown away.
Fred Claus tries desperately for a Bad Santa meets Elf vibe. Five minutes in, the man sitting next to me was sound asleep.
If you like schmaltzy, music-saturated family movies, This Christmas will set all the right bells jingling.
Let's avoid such extremes, and note merely that he's made a film that's funny ha-ha as well as funny peculiar; an exercise in navel-gazing that tickles all the senses.
I came, saw, had my retinas fried, and was conquered.
One day someone will make a film about a lone-wolf killer who gets offered One Last Job, turns it down, retires rich and lives happily ever after.
Ar-go see them in action.
Julian Temple's messy, whimsical look at the rise and fall of the British pub rock band Dr Feelgood packs a bigger punch than expected.
You'd have to be crazier than Joaquin Phoenix to see this film as ground-breaking. But when it's good, it ain't too bad at all.
A rom-com with brains that - at key moments - feels as sly and sweet as Annie Hall.
Are the camera moves graceful? Of course they are. Hypnotically graceful. Even the cigarette smoke looks like it's taken ballet lessons. But there's a bit more to the drama than meets the eye.
Thanks to the posturing, intrusive soundtrack and implausible, clichéd script, it's hard to take any of it too seriously.
The Silence is one of the most excruciating, paranoia-inducing films you'll see all year. Spread the word.
As with so many of Spielberg's blockbusters in the past 20 years, this one boasts technical innovation yet falls back on the most conservative kind of storytelling.
The problem lies with writer/director Arjun Rose, whose opportunism is matched only by his indifference to logic.
A haunting exploration of emotional and financial dependence that leaves you wondering if anyone can truly be said to stand on their own two feet.
Some movies are hard to spoof.
These smart actors are deconstructing their own glamour and seem far more scrumptious as a result.
Jespersen is a veteran comedian and he uses all his gravitas and dry wit to make us care about a lonely man on the verge of a crisis of faith.
I almost died laughing.
Jaunty, sad, poetic, Kes is so humane it makes you tremble.
If you're fascinated by the fall of Salvador Allende (who, of course, started his career as a physician) the wounded bodies on display will almost certainly break your heart.
A glossy fudge.
Why is the whole thing so watchable? Farrell is extremely good value. So is Toni Collette as the sex-starved but sensible single mom of high-school hero Charlie.
One of the funniest and most discombobulating films of the year.
A technically brilliant wildlife documentary from BBC Earth Film, let down by its gushy, absurdly pro-family script.
The Hackney-bound pals sulk, flirt and hoover up vast quantities of cocaine.
Cast and crew spin a twilight magic.
As in Todd Haynes's 1995 masterpiece, Safe, we are in a world that can't be pinned down.
What we're left with is a sporadically entertaining mess. Moneyball is unsure about what (if any) risks it should take.
Paquin, whose squirmy style of acting I've never liked, is astounding here...
This isn't the real Thing; keep it at bay.
Tim Burton loves paying homage to other movies. Here, just for a change, he does so to one of his own.
Flirtatious, hyper-aware, funny. What a champ.
movie_title: Queen - Hungarian Rhapsody: Live In Budapest '86 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: People will go to see this film for Streep. Its secret weapon is Jones.
Like Martin Scorsese's The Last Waltz, this is a documentary about a farewell concert.
movie_title: Shut Up and Play the Hits (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's testament to the non-scariness of A Night in the Woods that it makes you want to go out and buy a tent.
This whole caper is about as gritty as a babywipe.
One of those films you need to see twice, Miguel Gomes's subtle and bizarre little masterpiece unfolds slowly. Very slowly.

Certainly has its moments, yet lacks the tension of a real classic.
It's always dramatically satisfying when film-makers become part of the story; in this case, it's also politically instructive.
movie_title: Just Do It: A Tale of Modern-day Outlaws (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film is about law vs chaos. Via its images, it manages to take both sides.
Proof that you can create nerve-scraping twilight zones without A-list stars or CGI.
Here's something truly weird: as soon as I was back in the real world, Cosmopolis knocked me sideways.
Tari is headed for college; Sriywati is headed nowhere. By the time the credits roll, you ache for them both.
Pooley could have been more probing in her interviews with the twins and their supporters. But the fact of the duo's success is so astounding you're gripped all the same.
If originality were a crime, this film's screenplay wouldn't need a lawyer.
The script's central paradox - that dogmatic believers are the most adept at switching allegiance - is arresting.
A frustrating documentary about a frustrating man.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The chemistry between the actors is gorgeously unhealthy; Oedipal, spiteful and sexy.
It shouldn't work, but somehow it does.
I found myself lurching forwards and rocking with laughter.
Yusef's trials feel exquisitely urgent.

One of the most annoying things about the film is its smugness.
Basically very silly and wastes the time of some talented celebrities (including Lindsay Lohan, as an addled nymphet). But it has its moments.
You don't need to be interested in football to find Stewart Sugg's slick portrait of super-rich Manchester City FC involving.

French-made zombie flick The Horde isn't up there with Night of the Living Dead but still induces some unexpected gulps.
Just about bearable.
Director Nick Moran obviously feels strongly about the material but fails to create a consistent tone.

The Coen Brothers' O Brother Where Art Thou? was the last film to make such delirious use of mountain music. The rest of the world can start drooling over Lawrence. I'm gonna git me a copy of that soundtrack.
Cast and crew seem committed to making a simple point: "unhealthily close" relationships can be enriching. And the result is a movie that feels both small and deep.
As well as being conventional, The Girl Who Kicked is also confusing, dull and grubby (do we really need to see examples from a child-porn site?).
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's not so much a shock to the system as a series of practised strokes, yet -- for moments at a time -- it makes you squirm happily in your seat.
Breillat's ideas owes much to Angela Carter, yet The Bloody Chamber author would surely be depressed by the lack of dynamism on display.

When it comes to the things this brand is famous for -- angsty canoodling, ethereal rocking out, truckloads of male beauty, Duran Duran-style make-up and culturally savvy jokes -- Eclipse actually goes one better than the last offering.
I'd rather rot in a New Orleans jail than watch it again. And yet its epiphanies are outrageously sharp, it is beautifully shot by cinematographer Peter Zeitlinger and the ending is a joy.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It could have been a match made in heaven. The snake in the garden is a tired script from Rob and Mark Cullen, which purports to "spoof" Eighties buddy movies (Beverly Hills Cop, Lethal Weapon, etc) but lacks any real brain power of its own.

With great support from Eddie Marsan, Timothy Spall and young newcomer Nikita Mistry, humour and horror finally take a convincing hold of the plot and -- bibbidi-bobbidi-boo! -- an original idea gets transferred to the screen.

You realise that Martel knows exactly what she's doing and your heart starts to race.
movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Authentic and hyper-real, a reflection of a young girl's inner life that never strays into hysteria.
Here's a pretentious, cliché-ridden, London-set thriller notable for absolutely nothing.
The film is full of rows between Lev and his stagily irate wife. She's meant to be OTT - that's not the problem - it's the film itself that creaks.
It's Washington's Everyman who keeps the film honest.
Funny films are short on the ground and this one - which has already been dubbed a flop by US critics - deserves to be bigged up.

Treacle Jr won't win Oscars or swell the bank balances of cast and crew. In other words, it ain't The King's Speech. But I'd choose it over Tom Hooper's film any day, because it shows a London I recognise.
Fans of the genre will relish the ironies (or, as it's known in the trade, the chance to have your cake and eat it).
The word sexy is horribly overused. When it comes to this pair, though, it's the only word that will do.

Schmitz shoots the kids with dreamy respect. The adult actors have less to work with. Still, their agonised faces, not to mention their voices, create their own kind of texture and ensure we leave the cinema in tears.
Even those allergic to dance and/or the young will find themselves seduced.
Not so much triumphalist as upbeat, saucy rather than slick, Fire in Babylon is the kind of film that makes you proud to be a human being.
Win Win is slighter, and sappier, than it might have been. Still and all, it's a joy.
This cannily uncanny film resonates.
All three men give searing performances and young cinematographer Robert Hardy dwells with palpable relief on their expressive features.
This reboot may not be as revolutionary as it thinks, but it's definitely worth a second glance.

Writers Tony and Joe Gayton feed the trio just enough lines to make it seem like a team effort.
It seems guaranteed to infuriate anyone over seven.
Low expectations are the key to enjoying Wake Wood. You have been warned.
Harmless fun.
Chu has called Never Say Never "the origin story of a hero". Which is cobblers, obviously. But the film did convince me that Bieber is a dramatic figure.
Agonisingly slow and laughter-free.

PlanEat is on a serious mission but its lack of focus is infectious. My big question as the credits rolled: why are so many vegan chefs covered in tattoos?
Whenever Jarmusch lets his soundtrack - and his stars - do the talking, the right notes get struck.
All hail an uncanny British thriller.
If these actors felt they owed Goldsman a debt, they've paid it in full.

The beauty of the film lies in its refusal to paint Ben as a deluded tyrant or principled pioneer. He doesn't have two faces - thanks to the script, as well as Mortensen's squirrely brilliance, he has hundreds.
As with Starred Up, Mackenzie's family-centric prison drama, Hell or High Water is full of grim nooks and crannies.
The animation? Well, it robs you of breath, over and over again.
Allen's script throws together familiar elements (ruthless hoodlums, respectable hypocrites, insecure film buffs) but lacks pace, belly-laughs or texture.
Mia Hansen-Love's precise script, perfectly in tune with Huppert's methods, works like a sharp knife, gently able to slip between our ribs.
It's hard to explain how cleverly the film is structured without giving away crucial twists.
Never dull.
Solondz loves revisiting his creations (he did it in Life During Wartime and, glancingly, Palindromes). Alas, he never improves on the originals.
Finding Dory is inferior to Finding Nemo (and both Toy Story sequels). Those films are tesseracts, this one's a cube. That said, to label it average somehow misses the point.
Becomes so wedded to stodgy melodrama that you wind up thinking it's a bore to be that blue and just want to hear the man play.
Black lives matter. So does nuance.

Jackson is the film's greatest asset. He's also its biggest problem. He's just too charismatic.

Both predictable and confounding.
Elvis and Nixon are fascinating - if only we were allowed to spend more time with them.
You won't forget Remainder in a hurry.
Great. So now, along with being spooked by claps, dolls and nuns, I'm tisantaphobic too. Thanks for everything, James Wan.
While Guerra clearly owes a debt to Herzog and Coppola, he blazes his own trail. I can't wait to take this trip again.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If you're scared of twigs this movie will have you urinating in the aisles.

Bridget Jones's Baby, ultimately, snatches victory from the jaws of defeat.
This is a gory love story. It's a real gift.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If you like weird bedtime stories, hunt it down.
Crude but crafty ...
This lovely ode to change (which gets you thinking, not just about gender but all hierarchies) contains two powerful youngsters. It should really be called The Eaglet and her Girl.
Williams's wrenching yarn dissects various betrayals and offers a useful reminder: when it's all about the brand, we're all fair game.
Stone's film is about as suspenseful as a trip to Ikea.
In the next election, can I just vote Disney?
True, some of Paterson's poems are just dull-dull. And the whimsy can be cloying. But the acting is fantastic.
Shinkai is one to watch but doesn't quite yet deserve to be a household name.
I'm glad Indignation exists. In its own, quietly explosive way, it leaves a very human stain.
The confidently modest McCarthy creates her own happy endings. Make a date with this woman and you'll TF it's Friday.
At least, in its determinedly populist way, this violent character study makes you think.

Silly plot. Fancy locations.
A popsicle-coloured, 3D cartoon with a pertinent, if somewhat hard to explain conceit.
There's so much going on - too bad not a single encounter feels plausible or the least bit dangerous.
There are so many fascinating things about this film.
The Babadook's villains and victims are still running amok in my brain. I think they might be there for some time.
A great story, galumphingly told.
This is one of Burton's minor dreams but its yukky-yummy fragments are still doing cartwheels in my head.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I defy anyone to leave in a bad mood. James and Bob seem like good people. Or good cats.
It ain't rubbish, but Affleck's fly-by-night operation is still one to avoid.
Jones commands the SFX but (for now) he's lost the power to move.
This yummy film feels like a healthy choice for growing girls. Though it probably won't earn a billion dollars, what it offers is priceless.

Moore gets to wear a striking wig but has no dialogue that makes you look twice. And the more Stacie cries over her saintly lover, the more guiltily conscious you become that your own eyes are water-free.

It's entertaining at first that our heroine and hero can slay zombies as expertly as they parry quips but the joke wears thin.
Goosebumps combines cynicism with sweetness. If you can get past the slow start, woefully blank hero Zach (Dylan Minnette), and hit-and-miss special effects, you'll be charmed.

Larson delivers every line to perfection and, as it happens, there's not one weak link in the cast.

Like the anti-war saga In the Valley of Elah, A War explores a misuse of power that has horrific consequences. What's different is that here the crime takes place under our noses and, even more disturbingly, feels justified.

Given the circumstances, Read has done a wonderful job. Instead of promoting or smearing a celebrated brand he's created a portrait of a workplace that feels both pertinent to Putin's Russia and universal.

The landscapes are gorgeous; the ironies stark.
The huge, whale-sized problem is that Howard can't decide if this is dark, adult fare or a rollicking tale of derring-do.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: I love nature but halfway through Sunset Song I began to suffer from field fatigue. Cinematographer Michael McDonough shoots the soil and its various fruits with reverence - too much reverence.

True, your average broody careerist might struggle to find a gym-toned-cutie with a secret yearning to be a stay-at-home dad. Then again, what film doesn't encourage fantasies?
Chiwetel Ejiofor's new movie is a mess. Even the title - why are there more eyes than secrets? - induces brain ache.
Some may find Longoria's wry tone offensive but his playfulness is what make him worth watching. If laughter kills fear, this man is quite the slayer.

For all the high-tech lingo, there's nothing new to feel or see.
Carney nails every quirky detail.
How can you resist a film that, metaphorically, throws Simon & Garfunkel, Fugazi and Slayer into the same moshpit?

Bleak biopics don't have to be grim (think of Raging Bull). But this one is neither illuminating nor able to make the most of the dark.
A fitfully hilarious comedy sequel from Seth Rogen, the kind of man who can get away with pointing at a pregnant Hasidic woman and saying: "Look, another little Jew in the oven!"

More befuddled, plot-wise, than just about any other superhero epic of the last decade, Batman v Superman nevertheless deserves points for creating a vision of modern America that feels truly fractured.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Aware that gender, as much as faith, remains a burning issue, Eggers makes our hearts swell and our brains sweat.
The film is simultaneously sweet, simple and savvy.
The film's generous spirit keeps digging it out of trouble.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A reference to the Holocaust feels awkward, but otherwise the blend of personal and political is electrifying.
